newsitem.title: USA: Stocks mixed at midday, struggle to digest IPOs.
newsitem.headline: Stocks mixed at midday, struggle to digest IPOs.

text.p: Stocks were mixed in heavy trading Friday as earnings wariness made Wall Street cautious and the market struggled to digest more than a dozen initial public offerings.
Just after 1:10 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 9.25 points at 5,859.60 after earlier dropping nearly 24 points.
In the broader market, advancing issues beat decliners, 1,148-973 on heavy volume of 250 million shares.

"It looks like there's a lot of profit-taking in here and backing and filling, which is the type of activity associated with a short-term top. There are mixed opinions about whether the market will go higher or back off," said Thom Brown, a managing director of Rutherford Brown and Catherwood.
The Nasdaq Composite added 1.34 points to 1,229.32.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks shed 0.56 of a point to 685.31.
Economic news had little impact, though Thursday's unexpectedly weak August durable goods report continued to weigh on the market, raising worries about corporate earnings.

"There is some concern about the extent of how powerful earnings will be going forward, given the drop in durables," said Peter Green, a technical analyst at Gruntal. He noted warnings from such high-profile companies as AT&T Corp. and PepsiCo Inc.

"The idea that the Fed has indicated there are some signs of an economic slowing is a cause for concern, obviously because of their impact on corporate earnings. There are more earnings concerns creeping into this picture," Brown said.
The government reported its final revision to second-quarter gross domestic product, which came in at a 4.7 percent growth rate, a shade lower than the 4.8 percent reading previously reported.
Bonds lent little support. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32 to yield 6.88 percent, which was unchanged from Thursday's close.
Analysts said the spate of initial public offerings that hit the market cut into the enthusiasm for other issues.
Spanish-language TV broadcaster Univision Communications rallied 7-5/8 to 30-5/8 and Swiss watchmaker Tag Heuer International rose to 20 from its $19.55 a share offer price.

Cox Radio Inc. surged 3-5/8 to 22-1/8 in its Wall Street debut, Abacus Direct jumped 4 to 18, sunglasses maker Gargoyles Inc. climbed 4-3/4 to 20-3/4 and RockShox, a maker and deisgner of bicycle suspension products, added 1/4 to 15-1/4. Among other IPOs, Orckit Communications soared 4-1/8 to 20-1/8 and temporary employment concern Staffmark was up 1-3/4 to 13-3/4.

Meanwhile, Green saw near-term weakness for technology stocks, particularly semiconductor issues. He noted the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index, off two to 190, was not able to reach 200 and "is up against a minor wall."
The American Stock Exchange index was off 0.10 at 567.90.
